did.abstract: Vice-president and secretary of the University of Michigan; correspondence; research materials for his biographies of university presidents; files relating to activities on the Ann Arbor City Council; course notes from classes at the University of Michigan; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Shirley Wheeler Smith (donor no. 1718) and his estate (donor no. 3657). The bulk of the material came from the estate in 1960 and 1965.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Shirley Wheeler Smith Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Shirley Wheeler Smith was born May 3, 1875 in Nashville, Michigan. He graduated from the University of Michigan in 1897. He was an instructor in English from 1898 to 1901 at which time he was appointed secretary of the Michigan Alumni Association and editor of the Michigan Alumnus. He was named secretary of the University of Michigan by the Board of Regents in 1908 after working for four years as assistant in the president's office of the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Co. In 1927, Smith became secretary and business manager combined. In the 1930 administrative reorganization of the University, Smith was named vice-president and secretary, in which position he supervised all of the financial and business affairs of the University. He retired in 1945 devoting himself to scholarly interests that included biographies of U-M presidents James B. Angell and Harry B. Hutchins.

scopecontent.p: The Shirley Wheeler Smith papers include a combination of personal and professional materials. Much of Smith's career with the U-M is documented in the official records of the University, most notably in the records of the Secretary's Office and the papers of the presidents under whom he served (Angell, Hutchins, Burton, Little, and Ruthven). Even so, these papers contain much material relating to the business affairs of the U-M. The extensive correspondence files (with partial index) demonstrate wide influence in all phases of University operations as he corresponded with presidents, faculty, members of the board of regents, and other university personnel. Also documented in the collection is Smith's activities with the city of Ann Arbor and with other community organizations.

The collection has been arranged into the following series: Correspondence; Research for writings; Topical files; Ann Arbor City Council; Papers (by date); Personal and miscellaneous; and Photographs.

index.head: Selective Index to Correspondents
index.p: This index lists some of the more significant corespondents in the chronologically arranged portion of the Correspondence series. It cites the correspondent and the date(s) of correspondence.

list.item: June 10, 1907, June 27, 1907, June 21, 1943, Aug. 21, 1957 [Mrs. H. M. Bates]
May 4, 1944 [To A. H. Vandenberg], May 29, 1944 [To A. H. Vandenberg]
